Stabilizing elements: lack of AREs, protective 3' UTR structures that bind stabilizing proteins (beta-globin mRNA alpha-complex), long poly(A) tails maintained by cytoplasmic poly(A) polymerases, closed-loop structures (eIF4G-PABP interaction) that protect both ends. Biological rationale: Constitutive protein production with low transcriptional cost — transcribe once, translate many times before the mRNA is degraded. (3) Regulatory implications: The half-life determines how quickly a gene can be induced or repressed post-transcriptionally. Genes with short-lived mRNAs can change expression levels within minutes (e.g., immediate-early genes in response to growth factors). Genes with long-lived mRNAs change more slowly (hours), requiring ongoing transcription to maintain levels.
questions.topic: mRNA stability program and dynamic gene regulation

questions.question: The Trithorax group (TrxG) proteins maintain active gene expression states and are functionally antagonistic to Polycomb group (PcG) proteins. What is the primary mechanism by which TrxG complexes counteract PcG-mediated silencing?
options: TrxG proteins prevent PcG gene transcription by binding to PcG gene promoters
TrxG proteins function by degrading PcG proteins through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway
TrxG complexes are exclusively histone deacetylases that remove all modifications

TrxG complexes include MLL/SET1 methyltransferases that deposit H3K4me3 (antagonizing the repressive H3K27me3 mark), SWI/SNF chromatin remodelers that open chromatin (counteracting PRC1-mediated compaction), and the H3K27 demethylases UTX/KDM6A and JMJD3/KDM6B that directly remove PRC2-deposited H3K27me3
questions.explanation: Trithorax group proteins maintain active transcription states through multiple mechanisms that oppose Polycomb-mediated silencing: (1) TrxG methyltransferases: MLL1-4 (Mixed Lineage Leukemia) and SET1A/SET1B form COMPASS (Complex of Proteins Associated with Set1) complexes that deposit H3K4me1 (enhancers, by MLL3/4), H3K4me2, and H3K4me3 (promoters, by MLL1/2 and SET1A/B). H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 are generally mutually exclusive on the same histone tail (except in ESC bivalent domains). H3K4me3 recruits transcription-promoting effectors (TAF3 of TFIID, CHD1, BPTF/NURF) that counteract PcG-mediated repression. (2) SWI/SNF/BAF chromatin remodelers: SWI/SNF complexes (BAF, PBAF) use ATP hydrolysis to slide or eject nucleosomes, directly opposing the chromatin compaction caused by PRC1 (which compacts chromatin through H2AK119ub and Polyhomeotic/PHC-mediated SAM domain polymerization). BRG1 (the ATPase subunit of BAF) directly opposes PRC1 at many developmental gene promoters. Loss of BAF subunits leads to inappropriate PcG-mediated silencing of target genes. (3) H3K27 demethylases: UTX/KDM6A and JMJD3/KDM6B are Jumonji C (JmjC) domain-containing demethylases that specifically remove H3K27me2/me3 (converting to H3K27me1 and H3K27me0). UTX is a subunit of the MLL3/4 COMPASS complex, linking H3K27me3 removal to H3K4me1 deposition at enhancers during differentiation. JMJD3 is induced by developmental signals and inflammatory stimuli. (4) Genetic antagonism: In Drosophila, mutations in TrxG genes enhance PcG phenotypes (gain of silencing), while PcG mutations suppress TrxG phenotypes. This genetic antagonism reflects the biochemical opposition between H3K4me3 (TrxG) and H3K27me3 (PcG) and between chromatin opening (SWI/SNF) and compaction (PRC1). (5) Cancer relevance: Both TrxG and PcG components are frequently mutated in cancer. MLL translocations cause acute leukemias. SWI/SNF subunit mutations (SMARCB1, ARID1A, PBRM1) are found in ~20% of all cancers. EZH2 (PRC2) is both a tumor suppressor (loss in some cancers) and an oncogene (gain-of-function in lymphomas).

questions.question: Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) is the most widely used technique for mapping histone modifications and transcription factor binding. What is the key limitation of ChIP-seq that newer techniques like CUT&Tag address?
options: ChIP-seq cannot detect any histone modifications and is only useful for transcription factors

ChIP-seq requires millions of cells, extensive crosslinking, sonication that fragments epitopes, and immunoprecipitation that generates high background from non-specific DNA; CUT&Tag uses antibody-targeted Tn5 transposase (pA-Tn5) to fragment and tag DNA only at antibody-bound sites in situ, requiring far fewer cells (even single cells) with much lower background
Both techniques are identical in sensitivity, specificity, and cell number requirements
CUT&Tag requires more cells than ChIP-seq and produces lower-quality data
questions.explanation: CUT&Tag (Cleavage Under Targets and Tagmentation) represents a significant technical advance over traditional ChIP-seq: (1) ChIP-seq limitations: Requires 10^5-10^7 cells (impractical for rare cell types, clinical samples). Formaldehyde crosslinking (needed for TF ChIP) can mask epitopes and create artifacts. Sonication fragments DNA non-specifically, creating high background. Immunoprecipitation step has inherent noise (non-specific DNA binding to beads, antibody cross-reactivity). Requires 20-50 million sequencing reads for adequate genome coverage. Lengthy protocol (2-3 days). (2) CUT&Tag principle: Cells are bound to Concanavalin A magnetic beads. Primary antibody + secondary antibody bind the target in situ. Protein A-Tn5 transposase (pA-Tn5) preloaded with sequencing adapters binds the antibody. Upon activation with Mg2+, Tn5 fragments and simultaneously adaptor-tags DNA only near the antibody-bound site (tagmentation). Released fragments are collected and PCR-amplified for sequencing. (3) CUT&Tag advantages: Cell number: works with as few as 100 cells (single-cell CUT&Tag has been demonstrated). Background: dramatically lower because tagmentation only occurs at antibody-bound sites; bulk chromatin remains intact. Sequencing depth: 3-8 million reads suffice (vs. 20-50M for ChIP-seq). Speed: protocol completed in one day. No crosslinking or sonication needed for histone marks (native conditions preserve epitopes). (4) CUT&Tag limitations: Less suitable for transcription factors with transient DNA binding (may need light crosslinking). pA-Tn5 has some non-specific activity. Requires high-quality antibodies. Limited by Tn5 insertion bias at certain sequences.

questions.question: R-loops are three-stranded nucleic acid structures consisting of an RNA-DNA hybrid and a displaced single-stranded DNA. Where do functional R-loops form, and how do they influence gene expression?
options: R-loops are found exclusively in mitochondrial DNA and have no role in nuclear gene regulation
R-loops form only in bacteria during replication and do not occur in eukaryotes
R-loops always cause genome instability and are never beneficial for gene regulation

R-loops form at CpG island promoters where GC-rich sequences favor RNA-DNA hybrid stability; they prevent DNA methylation of the promoter by physically blocking DNMT3B access, protect CpG islands from de novo methylation, and can facilitate transcription initiation by maintaining an open chromatin state
questions.explanation: R-loops have both pathological and physiological roles in gene regulation: (1) Formation: R-loops form co-transcriptionally when nascent RNA re-anneals to the template DNA strand, displacing the non-template strand. Favored by high GC content, negative supercoiling, and G-rich non-template sequences forming G-quadruplexes. (2) At CpG island promoters (~60% of human gene promoters): R-loops physically prevent DNMT3A/3B from accessing DNA (DNMTs need dsDNA substrate), maintaining CpG islands hypomethylated and transcriptionally permissive. Loss of R-loops at some promoters leads to aberrant methylation and gene silencing. (3) At termination regions: R-loops downstream of poly(A) signals stall Pol II and facilitate torpedo termination by XRN2/Rat1, resolved by Senataxin helicase. (4) Pathological R-loops cause genome instability (displaced ssDNA is vulnerable to damage), transcription-replication conflicts, and neurodegeneration (Senataxin mutations cause ataxia). (5) Resolution by RNase H1/H2 (degrade RNA strand), Senataxin/SETX (helicase), and topoisomerases.

questions.question: The ENCODE project systematically mapped functional elements across the human genome. What was its most controversial finding?
options: ENCODE found no regulatory elements outside of protein-coding gene promoters
ENCODE discovered that the human genome contains only 5,000 genes
ENCODE found that 100% of the genome encodes proteins and there is no non-coding DNA

ENCODE reported that approximately 80% of the human genome has biochemical activity (transcription, TF binding, chromatin marks), but this was controversial because evolutionary conservation analyses suggest only 5-15% is under purifying selection, raising questions about whether biochemical activity equates to biological function or includes significant non-adaptive transcriptional noise
questions.explanation: ENCODE Phase 2 (2012) generated significant scientific debate: (1) Key finding: 80.4% of the genome assigned at least one biochemical function by at least one assay (RNA-seq, ChIP-seq, DNase-seq, FAIRE-seq across 147 cell types). This included: 76% transcribed into RNA, 8.1% with chromatin marks, 8.1% TF-bound, ~3% DNase-sensitive. (2) Controversy: Evolutionary biologists argued biochemical activity does not equal biological function. Only 5-8.5% shows evolutionary conservation (purifying selection). The remaining active sequences may be: spurious transcription through accessible chromatin, non-specific low-affinity TF binding, or chromatin mark consequences of nearby gene activity. (3) Current understanding: 5-15% under detectable purifying selection, additional fraction may have lineage-specific regulatory function, and much remaining genome consists of ancient transposable elements (45%). The operational definition of function (biochemical activity vs. evolutionary conservation vs. phenotypic consequence) remains debated.
questions.topic: ENCODE project and genome functionality debate
